CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: A certain network connection with a bandwidth of 12 Mbps allows making 4000 requests to a server per second. If each request is modified to have an additional data of 6 Kb, what should be the additional bandwidth required to maintain the rate of 4000 requests per second?
question_texts: A certain network connection with a bandwidth of 12 Mbps allows making 4000 requests to a server per second. If each request is modified to have an additional data of 6 Kb, what should be the additional bandwidth required to maintain the rate of 4000 requests per second?

questions.question_text_1: A client sitting in a train is connected to a server through a network tower that has a range of 4.5 kilometers and a constant bandwidth of 5 Mbps. The train is at a negligible distance from the tower and is moving away from it at a speed of 180 kmph. How much data (in Megabytes) will be used by the client before the train completely moves out of the coverage area, assuming that the client is consuming the entire bandwidth?
question_texts: A client sitting in a train is connected to a server through a network tower that has a range of 4.5 kilometers and a constant bandwidth of 5 Mbps. The train is at a negligible distance from the tower and is moving away from it at a speed of 180 kmph. How much data (in Megabytes) will be used by the client before the train completely moves out of the coverage area, assuming that the client is consuming the entire bandwidth?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements and choose the correct options.  Statement I: An author can write multiple books, but each book is written by only one author. Statement II: A publisher can publish multiple books, but each book is published by only one publisher. Statement III: A book belongs to one genre, but a genre can have multiple books.
question_texts: Consider the following statements and choose the correct options.  Statement I: An author can write multiple books, but each book is written by only one author. Statement II: A publisher can publish multiple books, but each book is published by only one publisher. Statement III: A book belongs to one genre, but a genre can have multiple books.

options.option_text: Statement I represents a many-to-many relationship between Author andBook.
Statement I represents a one-to-many relationship between Author and Book.
Statement II represents a one-to-many relationship between Publisher andBook.
Statement III represents a many-to-one relationship between Book and Genre.

questions.question_text_1: Match the URLs in column A with their correct rendered output in Column B with the correct app.py code for the flask application given in the previous question.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations #### HTML and CSS 1. **HTML Structure**: - Basic structure of an HTML document. - Use of tags like `

`, `

`, `

    `, `
  • `, and ``. 2. **CSS Styling**: - Inline styles and external stylesheets. - CSS selectors and properties like `color`, `background-color`, `border`, `display`, and `text-align`. - Specificity and the `!important` rule. 3. **Accessibility**: - Use of `alt` attributes for images. - Principles of web accessibility: Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, and Robust (POUR). #### Python and Flask 1. **Python Basics**: - String manipulation and templates. - Use of libraries like `string.Template` and `jinja2`. 2. **Flask Framework**: - Creating a Flask application. - Handling routes and HTTP methods (GET, POST). - Using `request` object to get query parameters. - Rendering templates and returning HTML responses. 3. **Command Line Arguments**: - Using `sys.argv` to get command-line arguments. - Running Python scripts with different arguments. #### Jinja2 Templating 1. **Template Rendering**: - Using `jinja2` to render templates with data. - Grouping data and conditional rendering. 2. **Template Inheritance**: - Extending and including templates. - Using blocks and placeholders. #### Networking and Bandwidth 1. **Bandwidth Calculation**: - Calculating additional bandwidth required for additional data. - Understanding data transfer rates and network coverage. 2. **Network Coverage**: - Calculating data usage based on speed and coverage area. #### Database Relationships 1. **Relationship Types**: - One-to-many relationships. - Many-to-one relationships. - Many-to-many relationships. #### Mathematical Equations 1. **Number Base Conversion**: - Converting numbers between different bases (e.g., octal, hexadecimal, decimal). - Solving equations with unknowns in different bases. ### Equations 1. **Bandwidth Calculation**: - Additional Bandwidth = Number of Requests per Second × Additional Data per Request - \( \text{Additional Bandwidth} = 4000 \, \text{requests/sec} \times 6 \, \text{Kb/request} \) - \( \text{Additional Bandwidth} = 24000 \, \text{Kbps} = 24 \, \text{Mbps} \) 2. **Data Usage Calculation**: - Data Usage = Bandwidth × Time - Time = Distance / Speed - \( \text{Time} = \frac{4.5 \, \text{km}}{180 \, \text{km/h}} = 0.025 \, \text{hours} = 90 \, \text{seconds} \) - \( \text{Data Usage} = 5 \, \text{Mbps} \times 90 \, \text{seconds} = 450 \, \text{Mb} = 56.25 \, \text{MB} \) 3. **Number Base Conversion**: - \( 1xy25_8 = 1 \times 8^4 + x \times 8^3 + y \times 8^2 + 2 \times 8^1 + 5 \times 8^0 \) - \( 1ED5_{16} = 1 \times 16^3 + E \times 16^2 + D \times 16^1 + 5 \times 16^0 \) - \( x89y_{10} = x \times 10^3 + 8 \times 10^2 + 9 \times 10^1 + y \times 10^0 \) ### Knowledge Graph ```mermaid graph TD; A[HTML and CSS] --> B[HTML Structure] A --> C[CSS Styling] A --> D[Accessibility] B --> E[Tags] B --> F[Attributes] C --> G[Selectors] C --> H[Properties] D --> I[POUR Principles] J[Python and Flask] --> K[Python Basics] J --> L[Flask Framework] J --> M[Command Line Arguments] K --> N[String Manipulation] K --> O[Templates] L --> P[Routes] L --> Q[HTTP Methods] L --> R[Request Object] L --> S[Rendering Templates] T[Jinja2 Templating] --> U[Template Rendering] T --> V[Template Inheritance] U --> W[Grouping Data] U --> X[Conditional Rendering] Y[Networking and Bandwidth] --> Z[Bandwidth Calculation] Y --> AA[Network Coverage] Z --> AB[Additional Bandwidth] AA --> AC[Data Usage] AD[Database Relationships] --> AE[One-to-Many] AD --> AF[Many-to-One] AD --> AG[Many-to-Many] AH[Mathematical Equations] --> AI[Number Base Conversion] AI --> AJ[Octal] AI --> AK[Hexadecimal] AI --> AL[Decimal] ``` ```mermaid graph TD; A[HTML Structure] --> B[Tags] A --> C[Attributes] B --> D[h1] B --> E[p] B --> F[ul] B --> G[li] B --> H[a] C --> I[src] C --> J[alt] C --> K[href] L[CSS Styling] --> M[Selectors] L --> N[Properties] M --> O[Class] M --> P[ID] N --> Q[color] N --> R[background-color] N --> S[border] N --> T[display] N --> U[text-align] V[Accessibility] --> W[POUR Principles] W --> X[Perceivable] W --> Y[Operable] W --> Z[Understandable] W --> AA[Robust] AB[Python Basics] --> AC[String Manipulation] AB --> AD[Templates] AD --> AE[string.Template] AD --> AF[jinja2] AG[Flask Framework] --> AH[Routes] AG --> AI[HTTP Methods] AG --> AJ[Request Object] AG --> AK[Rendering Templates] AH --> AL[/greet] AI --> AM[GET] AI --> AN[POST] AJ --> AO[request.args] AK --> AP[render_template] AK --> AQ[render_template_string] AR[Jinja2 Templating] --> AS[Template Rendering] AR --> AT[Template Inheritance] AS --> AU[Grouping Data] AS --> AV[Conditional Rendering] AT --> AW[Blocks] AT --> AX[Placeholders] AY[Networking and Bandwidth] --> AZ[Bandwidth Calculation] AY --> BA[Network Coverage] AZ --> BB[Additional Bandwidth] BA --> BC[Data Usage] BD[Database Relationships] --> BE[One-to-Many] BD --> BF[Many-to-One] BD --> BG[Many-to-Many] BE --> BH[Author and Book] BF --> BI[Book and Genre] BG --> BJ[Publisher and Book] BK[Mathematical Equations] --> BL[Number Base Conversion] BL --> BM[Octal] BL --> BN[Hexadecimal] BL --> BO[Decimal] ``` This summary and the knowledge graphs should help you understand the core topics and their relationships, making it easier to prepare for the exam.
